Box 98, 15 Bei San Huan East Road Beijing 100029 China Graphical abstract Growing demand of short chain olefins such as propylene for plastic production drives the development of high performing catalysts for propane dehydrogenation (PDH). Here, a confinement strategy originating from metal-sulfur clusters was employed to fabricate defective MoPtSx phase via anchoring by coordinatively unsaturated Al sites present on alumina, followed by reduction under H2 flow at high temperature. This catalyst with a low Pt content exhibits great ability for C–H activation with high intrinsic activity and facile propylene desorption in PDH reaction. More importantly, this catalyst shows excellent stability during long-term tests with both stable conversion and selectivity. Through combined X-ray absorption spectroscopy, electron microscopy and electron paramagnetic resonance measurements it could be affirmed that the isolated and electron-enriched Pt sites as well as their proximity to adjacent sulfur vacancies is vital for the first and second C–H bond activation, and suppressing of C–C cleavage which otherwise lead to coking. Keywords Isolated Ptδ- sites Adjacent S vacancies Propane dehydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene is a crucial basic raw material for the production of a wide range of chemicals in the chemical industry, and the generation of on-purpose propylene through catalytic propane dehydrogenation (PDH) has attracted considerable interest to satisfy growing global demand [1,2]. Platinum-based catalysts are often employed as the active site for the process of alkane dehydrogenation owing to its propensity for C–H bond activation [3,4]. However, this catalyst generally encounters challenges in associated with aggregation, lower propylene yield, an undesired cracking reaction and deactivation since a high reaction temperature (∼ 600 °C) is typically required given the high endothermicity (ΔH298 ϴ = 124.3 kJ/mol) and equilibrium-limitation of PDH[5,6,7]. Additionally, wider application is still a formidable challenge since precious metal resources are extremely scarce [8]. Consequently, the development of an innovative catalyst to realize the decrement of noble metal use whilst increasing efficiency is highly appealing. To tackle the aforementioned issues, a plethora of interesting catalysts have been designed to address these challenges. For instance, Pt-based intermetallics (involving Sn [9], Zn [10], Cu [11], Fe [12], Co [13], Ga [14] and In [15]) have been meticulously crafted that are typically more selective and stable, which contribute to higher propylene yields and inhibit carbon deposition by reason of the continuous Pt ensembles being broken by a second metal, albeit this is usually achieved at the expense of catalytic activity. Despite PDH being a structure insensitive reaction, the side reactions containing deep dehydrogenation, cracking, hydrogenolysis are structure sensitive meaning the particle size could remarkably influence the catalytic pathways [16]. Accordingly, reducing the particle size down to the atomic scale (i.e., the advent of single atom Pt) has revolutionized the atomic utilization of Pt with remarkable improvement of selectivity for PDH [17]. However, it is of course a challenge to retain complete isolation of Pt atoms in such a high temperature reaction. Recently, the deliberate use of vacancy engineering has drawn increasing attention in catalyst design. Benefiting from the optimization of both the electronic environment and chemical properties, vacancy mediation shows significant promise in regulating the catalytic behavior of C–H conversion to high value-added chemicals [18,19]. For instance, Deng et al. [20] found that the bi-Mo sites of sulfur vacancies at the MoS2 edge can dissociate O2 to form the active O = Mo = O* species, which can then activate a C–H bond. Motivated by this, if skillfully combining isolated Pt species and sulfur vacancies, it is expected to construct the advantageous active centers that simultaneously reinforce activity, selectivity and anti-coking performance for PDH. Metal-sulfur clusters are a class of inorganic compound that span a wide range of structural and electronic features. Specifically, the trinuclear Mo–sulfur cluster [Mo3(μ-S)3(μ3-S)Lx], where L is a ligand and x is the number of ligands present could offer a platform to accommodate a metal atom via three doubly bridging sulfur atoms to furnish a cubic structure [21,22]. Early studies on the synthetic Mo-S complexes such as [Mo6S8] revealed the roles of low-coordinated Mo available for the reaction in interacting with CO for methanol synthesis [23]. Also, the molybdenum-sulfur complexes have been found as efficient catalysts for the activation of C–H bond in alkane [24]. These findings provide insights into exploring novel catalysts for PDH. Herein, in this work, Pt was chosen as the additional metal to demonstrate the construction of isolated Pt atoms with neighboring sulfur vacancies. The catalyst, with low precious metal content delivers remarkable PDH performance with high propane conversion and high selectivity for propylene, and efficiently avoids deep dehydrogenation and cracking during long-term testing. On the basis of multiple in situ spectroscopic and microscopic characterizations, we found that the isolated Ptδ- species adjacent to sulfur vacancies is beneficial for activation of the C–H bond and favors the desorption of propylene via di-σ binding, therefore driving the conversion from propane to propylene. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemical materials H2PtCl6·6H2O was bought from Sigma-Aldrich. (NH4)2MoS4 and NaBH4 were purchased from Macklin. HCl was purchased from the Tianjin Damao chemical reagent factory. All materials were used as received without further purification. The water employed in all of the experiments was deionized. 2.2 Preparation of [Mo3Pt2S4(H2O)10] cluster precursor Aqueous solutions of 2 mol/L NaBH4 (15 mL) and 6 mol/L HCl (15 mL) were alternatively pipetted into a 110 mmol/L (NH4)2MoS4 aqueous solution (35 mL) under vigorous stirring at room temperature. Then, 60 mL of 6 mol/L HCl was added and the obtained mixture was heated to a temperature of 90 °C for 15 h. After cooling in air, this solution was transformed to a dark green [Mo3S4(H2O)9] solution. Subsequently, 0.078 g of H2PtCl6·6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water and then mixed with 4 mL of the [Mo3S4(H2O)9] solution to produce a [Mo3Pt2S4(H2O)10] precursor at room temperature. 2.3 Preparation of defective MoPtSx/Al2O3 catalysts Commercial γ-alumina was activated by pre-reduction with 10 % H2:N2 at 580 °C for 1 h to synthesize coordinatively unsaturated Al3+ sites (Al2O3-V), as reported previously [25]. 1.5 g of as-prepared Al2O3-V powder was added into an appropriate volume of [Mo3Pt2S4(H2O)10] solution under stirring at 60 ℃ for 4 h, followed by further drying at 60 ℃ for 12 h. After that, the obtained sample was heated to reaction temperature with a rate of 20 ℃·min−1 in N2 and then reduced in 10 % H2/N2 for 20 min to obtain defective MoPtSx/Al2O3 catalyst with sulfur vacancy, denoted as defective MoPtSx/Al2O3. The non-defective MoPtS/Al2O3 was prepared for comparison. In detail, the [Mo3Pt2S4(H2O)10]/Al2O3-V precursor was calcined at above temperature for 20 min in N2 with a heating rate of 20 ℃·min−1. Then, appropriate amounts of powders with NaBH4 were dissolved in 10 mL deionized water, and stirred for 30 min. After that, the suspensions were washed with deionized water and dried at 60 ℃ for 12 h. The reference Pt/Al2O3-V, Pt-S/Al2O3-V and Pt-Mo/Al2O3-V samples were prepared in a similar manner but using corresponding H2PtCl6·6H2O, NaS2 and (NH4)2Mo7O24·4H2O as the Pt, S and Mo sources, respectively. 2.4 Catalytic testing Catalytic behavior was evaluated in a fixed-bed microreactor at a pressure of 0.1 MPa. In detail, 0.13 g of sample was diluted with quartz sand (Aldrich, 40–70 mesh) and placed in the reactor and activated (as above), then an inlet gas stream of 2.0 % C3H8/4% H2/94 % N2 to obtain a weight hourly space velocity of 1.47 h−1. The reactant and product concentrations were analyzed by online Gas Chromatography (GC) with a flame ionization detector using a HP-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm). Multiple data points were collected for a given set of conditions to ensure data reproducibility. Propane conversion, propylene selectivity, turnover frequency, propylene productivity rate and deactivation rate constant were calculated as following: P r o p a n e c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = p r o p a n e i n l e t - p r o p a n e ( o u t l e t ) p r o p a n e ( i n l e t ) P r o p y l e n e s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = p r o p y l e n e o u t l e t p r o p a n e i n l e t - p r o p a n e ( o u t l e t ) T u r n o v e r f r e q u e n c y ( s - 1 ) = C × L × M × 10 - 3 V m × m × w × D × 60 P r o p e n e p r o d u c t i v i t y r a t e ( m m o l · g c a t . - 1 · m i n - 1 ) = L × C × S m × V m D e a c t i v a t i o n r a t e c o n s t a n t ( m i n - 1 ) = l n 100 - C e n d C e n d - l n 100 - C s t a r t C s t a r t t where C is propane conversion (%); L is the flow rate of propane (mL·min−1); Vm is the molar volume of a gas (L·mol−1); M stands for atomic mass of Pt; m is catalyst amount (g); w is the metal loading (wt. %); D is metal dispersion (%); S is propylene selectivity; Cstart and Cend indicates the initial and final propane conversion (%), respectively; t indicates time on stream (min). 2.5 Catalyst characterization A Shimadzu ICPS-7500 Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometer (ICP-AES) was used to determine the elemental content of metals. A Vario UNICUBE Organic Elemental Analyser (EA) was employed for elemental determination of S. Powder X-ray Diffraction (XRD) data was obtained in the range of 2θ = 10–80° using Cu Ka radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) in a SHIMADZU XRD-6000 instrument. HRTEM measurements were performed using a JEOL-2010F transmission electron microscope with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Quasi-in situ atomic resolution HAADF-STEM images were acquired on a probe aberration-corrected FEI Titan Themis Z microscope operating at 300 kV. Elemental mapping analysis was carried out with a Super X-EDS system operating at 200 kV. Solid state UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were collected at room temperature in air using a UV-3600 spectrometer. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was performed on an ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with Al Kα radiation using the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV as reference. Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded at low temperature on a Bruker ESP-300 spectrometer operating at X-band microwave frequency. In situ infrared spectra of adsorbed CO or O2 were acquired using a Bruker Tensor 27 instrument with a crystal quartz reaction cell and KBr windows. The sample powder was purged Ar to record a background spectrum. The spectra of adsorbed CO or O2 were obtained after introducing 99.99 % CO or 20.99 % O2/N2 into the reactor for 60 min and purging with Ar for a further 60 min to remove any gas-phase molecules. Temperature programmed experiments were conducted using a Micrometrics ChemiSorb 2750 instrument with a Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD). 0.10 g of sample was placed in the center of a quartz tube and pre-treated at 120 °C for 30 min in Ar to remove the impurities, followed by cooling to room temperature. For a C3H6-TPD experiment, C3H6 was passed through until the sample was saturated, then purged with He for 60 min to remove any physically adsorbed C3H6. Finally, the desorption signal was recorded as the temperature was increased from 25 to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 oC·min−1. Thermo Gravimetric analysis (TG) profiles were recorded using a HITACHI STA7300 instrument. The samples were heated in the temperature range of 25–400 °C with a heating rate of 10 oC·min−1 under a flow of air. The dispersion of Pt in the catalyst was estimated by CO-pulse chemisorption, in which a CO/Pt stoichiometry of 1 has been assumed for calculation of the dispersion. Raman spectrum was obtained on a LabRAM Aramis spectrometer with a 532-nm excitation laser, operated at an exposure time of 1 s and three accumulations. Solid State NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker 400WB AVANCE Ⅲ instrument. 27Al NMR experiments were carried out using a 4 mm triple-resonance broadband solid-state probe with a spinning rate of 8 kHz. The spectra were accumulated for 120 scans with 2 s recycle delay. The chemical shifts were referenced to a 1 % Al(NO3)3 aqueous solution. C3H8-Temperature Programmed Surface Reaction (TPSR) experiment was performed in a high-pressure reaction cell. About 0.2 g of sample was pretreated in H2/N2 for 20 min. Then, the gas was switched to 5 % C3H8/N2 with flow rate of 40 mL/min and heating from 30 to 600 °C for data recording. The output products (m/z of C3H8, C3H6, CH4 being 29, 41, 16, respectively) were measured via mass spectrometer. Quasi in situ X-ray Absorption spectra (Pt L-edge) were conducted at the 1W1B beamline of the National Synchrotron Light Source II at the Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility. The sample was protected under a N2 atmosphere to prevent re-oxidation in air, followed by measurement in the transmission/fluorescence mode. The typical energy of the storage ring was 2.5 GeV with a maximum current of 250 mA. Using a Si (111) double-crystal monochromator, the data collection was carried out in transmission/fluorescence mode using an ionization chamber. Data reduction, data analysis and EXAFS fitting were performed and analyzed with the Athena and Artemis programs of the Demeter data analysis packages that utilize the FEFF6 program to fit the EXAFS data. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Preparation of precursor via confinement of unsaturated cubane structure A [Mo3S4(H2O)9] cluster with an unsaturated cubane structure was firstly prepared by reacting ammonium tetrathiomolybdate with NaBH4 and HCl. This was followed by introducing an appropriate amount of H2PtCl6 as Pt source to generate [Mo3Pt2S4(H2O)10] clusters based on the Pt/Mo atomic ratio experimentally measured (Table S1). This was confirmed by XRD patterns (Fig. S1) and UV–VIS analysis (Fig. S2), in which the characteristic peaks of [Mo3S4(H2O)9] appear consistent with the literatures [26,27]. Notably, a new peak appears at 451 nm after incorporation of Pt, which could be ascribed to the spin forbidden metal–ligand charge transfer (MLCT) transitions owing to the binding of Pt with S, Mo or water ligands [28,29]. This above phenomena indicates that a Pt ion was successfully introduced into the cubane cluster. Coordinatively unsaturated Al2O3-V was used as support in this work. Different from the bulk alumina, the obvious penta-coordinated Al3+ species (11.3 %) is observed as shown in Fig. S3. After supporting [Mo3Pt2S4(H2O)10] cluster, it is interestingly found that the peak intensity of penta-coordinated Al3+ species is significantly reduced, implying that the active cluster species are mainly anchored on the coordinatively unsaturated sites. Similar phenomena were also reported by Kwak et al. [30] and Shi et al. [31]. Notably, an analogous Pt free sample was also prepared for comparison using the [Mo3S4(H2O)9] cluster and the same Al2O3-V support. In order to explore the crystal structure, XRD characterization was conducted. Fig. S1 shows that diffraction peaks present at 31.7°, 39.1° and 45.5° associated with the (220), (222) and (400) planes of Al2O3 (PDF#74–2206), respectively. In addition, the characteristic peaks attributed to the [Mo3S4(H2O)9] cluster are preserved after supported individually at the pentacoordinated Al sites in alumina [32]. Importantly, the introduction of Pt cations occurs without any evidence of diffraction peaks associated with metallic Pt or PtO2 indicating the structural stability of the molybdenum sulfur clusters during the preparation process. Similarly, no obvious Pt agglomerations were observed in HRTEM images with Pt, Mo and S elements parallelly dispersed at the atomic level in Fig. 1 and S4. Considering the low resolution of HRTEM analysis, STEM equipped with mapping was further employed (Fig. 2A-C). The [Mo3Pt2S4(H2O)10]/Al2O3-V exhibits small clusters. By further magnification, the brightest spots are expected to be associated with Pt since it possesses the highest atomic number and therefore appears to be parallel distributed across the support, which further indicates that Pt is successful anchored by the [Mo3S4(H2O)9] clusters. 3.2 Formation of a defective MoPtSx phase after reduction Subsequently, the supported precursors were reduced and XRD results are shown in Fig. S5. Characteristic peaks appear at 39.1°, 45.3° and 66.2°, 2 thetas of which are higher compared to that of Mo3S4 (JCPDS#97-004-2133), and lower relative to that of Pt particles (PDF#88-2343), but located between these both, indicating that Pt and Mo3S4 mutually entry into the lattice to form a MoPtSx solid solution. Similar phenomena could be observed in Ni-Cu alloys, reported by Koustuv Ray et al. [33]. Again, it is worth noting that no characteristic peaks associated with Pt are observed in the XRD pattern, which suggests that the active Pt species anchored/dispersed by the cubane cluster remains highly dispersed as a legacy effect even after high-temperature reduction. The above phenomena are initially attributed to the formation of MoPtSx phase. AC-STEM analysis equipped with mapping was further conducted (Fig. 2 D-H). The presence of lattice fringes is 0.216 nm (Fig. 2F), which is between Pt nanoparticles and Mo3S4 phase, and different from Pt-S and Pt-Mo particles. Combining with elemental mapping showing that a parallel distribution of Pt, Mo and S elements in the region sample (Fig. 2H), the formation of MoPtSx phase is undeniably confirmed. Although the size in the MoPtSx catalyst is larger (4.6 ± 0.2 nm, Fig. S6) than simple Pt catalyst with an average particle size of 1.5 nm (based on analysis of > 200 nanoparticles, Fig. S7), the former exhibits higher Pt dispersion owing to the generation of MoPtSx phase with isolated Pt sites. Additionally, the reduction of [Mo3Pt2S4(H2O)10] precursors contribute to the phase transformation, in which the crystallization water in the cluster is removed but remains the unchanged atomic ratio of Pt and Mo, while S element is easily formed into hydrogen sulfide gas in this environment to overflow (Table S1), and thus forms sulfur vacancies[34]. To further explore this concept, XPS spectra of S species before and after the reduction are presented in Fig. 2J. The peaks at 162.4 eV and 163.7 eV in [Mo3Pt2S4(H2O)10] catalysts are attributed to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of S2-, respectively [35], while the signal associated with S species in the reduced MoPtSx catalyst decreases due to the loss of S species at reduction. EPR results (Fig. 2I and S8), show a signal at g = 2.003 for defective MoPtSx catalyst but no signal for non-defective MoPtS and Pt catalysts as contrast, suggesting the existence of S vacancies in MoPtSx/Al2O3-V. To give enough evidence for the formation of S vacancy, in situ DRIFTS spectra with pulsing oxygen were employed. Fig. 2K shows that defective MoPtSx/Al2O3-V presents the absorption peaks at 975 cm−1 corresponding to the Mo-O vibrations due to oxygen adsorbed at S vacancies adjacent Mo species, which does not appear in non-defective MoPtS/Al2O3-V as contrast (Fig. S9). Additionally, due to the limitations of the present characterizations, it is very difficult to effectively distinguish the sulfur vacancies on the surface or subsurface. 3.3 Catalytic performance in propane dehydrogenation The above obtained catalysts were then explored for the propane dehydrogenation reaction. ICP-AES analysis confirms that all Pt catalysts have equivalent Pt loading which excludes the influence of Pt content on catalytic performance (Table S1). Fig. 3 A-3C show plots of propane conversion and product selectivity versus reaction time over both catalysts at 580 °C. It can be seen that the initial conversion over defective MoPtSx/Al2O3-V could reach 64 % with excellent propylene selectivity (> 90 %), which is much higher than the conversion typically reported in literatures for highly or atomically dispersed Pt catalysts (Table S2), and is even approaching the equilibrium conversion at 580 °C (81.9 %, Fig. S10). Although the monometallic Pt catalyst also exhibits good initial activity (40 %), the propylene selectivity at corresponding conversion is poorer (58–83 %) than that of defective MoPtSx/Al2O3-V, since monometallic Pt is prone to deep dehydrogenation and cracking (namely undesirable C−C cleavage) to generate C1 and C2 by-products (methane and ethylene in Fig. 3C). The amounts of C1 and C2 by-products are extremely low although C2 selectivity is slight higher than C1, and thus such small gap will be ignored in this case. However, there is no doubt that more by-products produced by C–C breakage in Pt samples result in high deactivation rate constant than defective MoPtSx/Al2O3-V (Fig. 3D). To explore the role of the species containing Mo and S, Mo3Sx benchmarks were firstly tested. The low conversion demonstrates that only Mo or S species are not active sites (Fig. S11) although the previous references reported the existence of O = Mo or MoS2 as active sites for dehydrogenation [20]. This may be ascribed to the pre-reduction of the sample at reaction temperature before the test, which might remove the possible O = Mo = O* active species. However, the introduction of Mo could effectively improve the selectivity of propylene by comparing Pt-Mo (85 %, Fig. S12) with Pt catalysts (<80 %). Furthermore, a simple PtSx catalyst possessing the sulfur vacancy was fabricated under same conditions, which gives higher initial conversion and selectivity relative to monometallic Pt catalysts. It is inferred that the combination of Pt, Mo, S and sulfur vacancy are important for the improvement of product selectivity and conversion. Follow this instruction, the MoPtS catalysts without sulfur vacancies (namely non-defective) was further employed. Its catalytic performance could be improved but limited (43.5 % conversion, 52.5 kJ/mol of activation energy and 82.0 % selectivity in Figure S12 and S13), suggesting the role of sulfur vacancies, being synergistic with adjacent Pt species, and thus directionally drive reaction process. In addition to propane conversion and propylene selectivity, turnover frequency (TOF) is also an important parameter to evaluate the intrinsic activity. In order to exclude the influence of mass and heat transfer, TOF was calculated from data at < 15 % conversion and the calculated values for the Weisz–Prater and Mears criterion are lower than 1 (see Supplementary Information, Table S3). Strikingly, the defective MoPtSx catalyst gives a TOF value of 0.46 min−1, which is about 2-fold higher than the Pt catalyst in-spite of the Pt sample having a lower dispersion (Fig. 3E). In other words, this highlights that the electronic/geometric environment of Pt in MoPtSx/Al2O3-V leads to a highly active form of Pt and this is discussed further below. When compared with the state of art catalysts reported in literatures [36,37,38], our defective MoPtSx catalyst offers a unique combination of high activity and high selectivity (Fig. 3F). This is unusual since high selectivity is often achieved at the expense of activity. Meanwhile, the activation energy (Ea) derived from the slope of ln TOF versus 1000/T over defective MoPtSx catalyst (43.9 kJ/mol, Fig. 3H) is obviously smaller than that of Pt/Al2O3-V (54.8 kJ/mol, at the same temperature range), the difference of which could be generally ascribed to the change of active species. To further identify the active species, Ea of contrastive Pt-Mo, Pt-S and MoPtS/Al2O3-V without sulfur vacancy have been prepared and evaluated as shown in Fig. S13. As expected, it is found that the apparent activation energies of Pt-Mo, Pt-S and non-defective MoPtS/Al2O3-V are much higher than that of defective MoPtSx, suggesting the ascendant active species need to the synergism of Pt, Mo, S elements to form MoPtSx phase with sulfur vacancy. More interestingly, greater C–H bond activation ability of the MoPtSx structure also facilitates the production of propylene compared with Pt catalyst, shown in Fig. 3G. Furthermore, under typical propane dehydrogenation conditions at 520 °C, C3H8 conversion of defective MoPtSx/Al2O3-V shows a slight fluctuation for C3H8 conversion through a 100 h long-term period with C3H6 selectivity being stable at about 93 % (Fig. 3I), indicating the good stability of Pt catalysts anchored by [Mo3S4(H2O)9] clusters. However, the conversion of monometallic Pt/Al2O3-V decreases rapidly under the same reaction conditions (Fig. S14). 3.4 Structure-performance relationship in propane dehydrogenation According to the above results, the fabrication of a MoPtSx phase by utilizing the structural characteristics of an unsaturated cubane cluster facilitates the enhancement of catalytic behavior. To gain insight into the essence of the structure-performance relationship, in situ CO-IR analysis was first carried out to explore the adsorption mode of CO molecules on the catalyst surface (Fig. 4 A). Note that two CO adsorption bands appear at 2055 and 1840 cm−1 on Pt/Al2O3-V, which are attributed to the linear and bridge adsorption of CO on Pt ensembles, respectively [39]. However different with the continuous Pt trimers, two new CO absorption bands are observed at 2112 cm−1 and 2004 cm−1, for the [Mo3Pt2S4(H2O)10] precursor, suggesting the presence of oxidized and metallic Pt single atoms [40]. Interestingly, the defective MoPtSx catalyst obtained after reduction only shows one absorption band at 2043 cm−1 which is attributed to linearly adsorbed CO on isolated Pt sites [41]. This interpretation would be consistent with the proposed structure of the precursor before reduction and the apparent stability/lack of agglomeration after high temperature treatment due to the confinement effect of the cluster precursor. Compared with Pt catalyst, the CO absorption band for defective MoPtSx/Al2O3 appears at lower wavenumber, indicating that the Pt species is in an enriched electron state [42]. Furthermore, the normalized Pt L-edge extended X-ray absorption fine spectrum (EXAFS) spectra were conducted to study the electronic and geometric structure of MoPtSx samples in contrast to Pt foil, PtO2 and PtS2 sample. As shown in Fig. 4B, S15 and S16, different from PtO2 or PtS2 references presenting a narrow peak at 1.6 or 1.8 Å, MoPtSx samples exhibit a wider peak involving Pt-S coordination at 1.8 Å and Pt-Mo coordination at 2.3 Å by deconvoluting [43]. The R of latter, namely Pt-Mo shell is lower than pristine Pt-Pt one due to smaller atomic radius of Mo; meanwhile, there is also no pristine Pt-Pt contribution at 2.6 Å (such as Pt foil). By combining XAS analysis with XRD and STEM results showing the lattice fringes of 0.216 nm, it could be concluded that Pt species are completely isolated by Mo and S to form MoPtSx phase, rather than PtS or Pt ensembles. Additionally, EXAFS data-fitting results (Table S4) manifest that the coordination number (CN) of Pt-S and Pt-Mo in the target catalysts are 2.7 and 1.1, while the Pt-Pt and Pt-O coordination are absent, verifying that predominant Pt atoms are discontinuous and surrounded by three S atoms and one Mo atom. To further gain visual illustrations of Pt coordination conditions, wavelet transform (WT) of the k3-weighted EXAFS spectra, a reflection of structure information in the resolution of R space and K space, are shown in Fig. 4. MoPtSx catalyst exhibits the maximum WT intensity at 1.4–1.8 Å in R space and 3–7 Å in k space, ascribing to Pt-S bond in the first coordination shell [44], while another WT intensity near 2.3 Å and 8–10 Å suggests the existence of Pt-Mo bonds. This also demonstrates Pt species are diluted by S and Mo without Pt-Pt and Pt-O coordination. Note that there are four S atoms in the cluster precursors, that is to say some S species overflows to form sulfur vacancies during the reduction process. Since the binding energy of Pt 4f and Al 2p are very close, it is difficult to clearly distinguish these two elements, thus the Pt 4d orbital is selected for analysis. As shown in Fig. 4D, two peaks are attributed to the 4d5/2 and 4d3/2 states of Pt species [45]. The Pt 4d5/2 region in the spectrum of Pt catalyst can be deconvoluted into two peaks corresponding to metallic Pt0 at 315.4 eV and oxidized Pt4+ at 318.4 eV, respectively [46]. The generation of latter is associated with re-oxidation in air during sample handling. For the MoPtSx sample, it exhibits a negative shift (314.6 eV) by 0.8 eV compared with monometallic Pt/Al2O3-V (315.4 eV), indicating that the Pt species derived from the Mo-S cluster precursor are electron rich (i.e., Ptδ-) which is in agreement with the CO-IR discussion above. In combination with EPR and S 2p XPS results, it is thought that the Ptδ- species originates from interaction with a neighboring S vacancy and the resulting electronic state of Pt is beneficial with regards to adsorption and desorption of reactants or products. Studies have shown that the adsorption and desorption of reactants/products are affected by the filling state of the d-orbital of the active metal. When the d-band center is far away from the Fermi level, the filling degree of the anti-bonding orbital will increase. From the valence band spectra presented in Fig. S17, we could see the d-band center of the MoPtSx catalyst shifts away from the Fermi level compared with Pt catalyst (3.13 eV), the displacement of which is due to the electron transfer to Pt (in accordance with XPS analysis). Consequently, the filling of the d-orbital in Pt increases, which could weaken the adsorption strength of propylene. Generally, the rapid desorption of C3H6 can effectively inhibit further dehydrogenation or cracking of propylene, which significantly improves selectivity to propylene during PDH. Indeed, as shown in C3H6-TPD results (Fig. 4G), the temperature and peak intensity for bridge bound propylene adsorption (300–420 °C region) on MoPtSx/Al2O3-V are both lower than for Pt/Al2O3-V (Table S5), indicating that C3H6 is expected to desorb more easily from the Ptδ- sites, thus showing better propylene selectivity. We further compare the activity using a temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR). Both the first and second steps of C–H activation can limit dehydrogenation activity in PDH. The MoPtSx catalyst starts to convert propane to the C3H7* intermediate with initial C–H cleavage at ca. 260 °C whereas the monometallic Pt NPs are active only at temperatures above 325 °C (Fig. 4H and 4I). Moreover, the onset temperature for propylene formation (i.e., the second C–H bond cleavage) is at 329 °C for MoPtSx/Al2O3-V, which is more favorable than that of Pt/Al2O3-V (460 °C). Interestingly, the formation of CH4 is observed at 450 °C for Pt/Al2O3-V, but not over MoPtSx catalyst. This demonstrates that the activity, that is, C–H activation, is significantly improved by introducing the isolated Pt atoms with the adjacent sulfur vacancies and this also restricts cracking and deep dehydrogenation reactions. However, Pt nanoclusters tend to decompose into methane and coke instead of undergoing dehydrogenation. 3.5 Insight into the improved stability Given that propane dehydrogenation is a strongly endothermic reaction, the active metal can agglomerate and deactivate due to coking at such high reaction temperature (500–700 °C). However, the MoPtSx catalyst displays excellent stability (Fig. 3I). Two driving factors could explain this stability. Firstly, structural stability is revealed through no significant change in Pt, Mo, S element content (Table S1) and particle size of MoPtSx/Al2O3-V before and after the long period reaction (spent = 4.7 nm in Fig. S18 vs fresh = 4.6 nm in Fig. S6), whereas the particle size of Pt/Al2O3-V increases significantly under equivalent conditions (used = 4.6 nm in Fig. S19 vs fresh = 1.5 nm Fig. S7). The EXAFS characterization of spent MoPtSx/Al2O3-V indicates the coordination structure of Pt with adjacent S and Mo largely remain unchanged (Fig. 4B), which is ascribed to that the unsaturated vertex vacancy of [Mo3S4(H2O)9] clusters could effectively anchor Pt atoms and inhibit the agglomeration, manifesting high stability. Moreover, the intensity of white line peaks in XANES spectra is almost same for the fresh and spent MoPtSx samples (Fig S20), indicating no significant change in electron density of Pt species before and after reaction. Furthermore, the amount of coke formed on the spent catalysts was provided by performing TGA analysis (Fig. S21), in which no obvious weight loss is showed from the spent MoPtSx sample (beyond dehydration), whereas the Pt sample shows about 10 % weight loss originating from carbon deposition. Operando Raman spectra offers the nature of coke deposits in PDH reaction. Typical signals of coking involving D and G band could be distinguished in Fig. S22, in which G band, at 1595 cm−1, originating from the doubly degenerate phonon mode with E2g symmetry at the Brillouin zone for perfect graphite lattices. An intense D1 band, at 1325 cm−1, responding to double-resonant Raman scattering of the graphene lattices with defects and in-plane transverse optic phonon modes, whose intensity generally grows with reduction of graphite crystallites. The shoulder (D3 band) at 1220 cm−1 is owing to amorphous one, while D4 band at 1495 cm−1 is assigned to disordered graphitic lattices with A1g symmetry. That is to say, the value of IG/ID1 represents the graphite degree of carbon deposition, which is too inert to remove. From these results, it is found that the construction of Ptδ- sites adjacent to S vacancy prevents cracking to coking and further transformation of the coke species into perfectly crystallized graphite, while a higher degree of graphitization is obtained in the coking process over Pt catalyst as contrast. In conclusion, we designed and successfully synthesized a novel propane dehydrogenation catalyst by applying a molybdenum-sulfur cubane cluster as a means of anchoring/dispersing Pt prior to depositing onto an Al2O3-V support. After hydrogen reduction, the Pt species remains atomically dispersed but with neighboring sulfur vacancies that yield an electron-enriched Ptδ- site as an active center for highly selective PDH. The resulting Pt geometric and electronic properties were synergistic and enhanced C–H activation whilst favoring propylene desorption resulting in both high activity and high propylene selectivity (even at relatively high propane conversion). Moreover, the PtMoSx catalyst exhibited long term stability due to the excellent resistance to C − C bond cleavage. The catalyst design concept established in this work breaks a new horizon for improving the catalytic behavior of Pt-based catalysts in alkane dehydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Growing demand of short chain olefins such as propylene for plastic production drives the development of high performing catalysts for propane dehydrogenation (PDH). Here, a confinement strategy originating from metal-sulfur clusters was employed to fabricate defective MoPtSx phase via anchoring by coordinatively unsaturated Al sites present on alumina, followed by reduction under H2 flow at high temperature. This catalyst with a low Pt content exhibits great ability for C–H activation with high intrinsic activity and facile propylene desorption in PDH reaction. More importantly, this catalyst shows excellent stability during long-term tests with both stable conversion and selectivity. Through combined X-ray absorption spectroscopy, electron microscopy and electron paramagnetic resonance measurements it could be affirmed that the isolated and electron-enriched Pt sites as well as their proximity to adjacent sulfur vacancies is vital for the first and second C–H bond activation, and suppressing of C–C cleavage which otherwise lead to coking.

coredata.dc:title: Cuboidal molybdenum sulfur cluster as a platform to construct novel catalyst for propane dehydrogenation
